citation.abstract:
To evaluate the safety and effectiveness of early versus late enteral nutrition support in patients with severe thermal injuries.
The PubMed, Ovid, Cochrane Library, Elsevier Science, ProQuest, and Springer databases were searched for randomized trials that compared the application of early enteral nutrition (EEN) to late enteral nutrition (LEN).
Six trials with 265 patients were analyzed. EEN did not significantly affect the mortality rate (RR=0.75, 95%CI=[0.41, 1.39], P=0.37>0.05), the rate of sepsis (RR=0.70, 95%CI=[0.45, 1.09], P=0.12>0.05), or the wound infection rate (RR=0.61, 95%CI=[0.27, 1.37], P=0.23>0.05). In addition, three trails examined length of stay and found that EEN significantly increased the length of ventilator days (RR=0.42, 95%CI=[0.02, 0.81], P=0.04<0.05); however, EEN was not significantly associated with a decrease in the duration of antibiotic therapy (RR=-0.04, 95%CI=[-0.43, 0.36], P=0.85). Outcome data that could not be pooled for analyses were described in detail.
This study indicated that EEN does not have a profound effect on the prognosis of people with severe thermal injury and further studies are needed to verify its safety. Only the analysis considering the number of ventilator days suggested that EEN had negative effects (i.e., prolonged the ventilation period).This study also highlighted the need for high-level randomized controlled trails comparing EEN and LEN.
citation.title: Early enteral nutrition versus late enteral nutrition for burns patients: A systematic review and meta-analysis.
